newsitem.title: GERMANY: German SPD says coalition tax reform plan lacking.
newsitem.headline: German SPD says coalition tax reform plan lacking.

text.p: Germany's opposition Social Democrats (SPD) said on Friday the coalition's latest tax reform proposals fell short of the mark and the SPD saw no reason to drop its intention to block the reform in the upper house of parliament.

Peter Struck, parliamentary faction leader of the SPD, told Inforadio in Berlin that the SPD remained firmly opposed to the coalition's plans to gradually raise taxes on pay for weekend and evening shifts.
The SPD also rejects the coalition's unchanged stance on trimming tax breaks for commuters.
"The coalition has shown some willingness to compromise on the taxes for weekend and night shift bonus pay," Struck said. "But that does not go far enough."
Chancellor Helmut Kohl's embattled coalition agreed on Thursday on reforms to plug new holes in the budget that emerged because of lower tax revenue estimates.

The coalition has teetered on the brink of collapse because the liberal Free Democrats (FDP) adamantly refused to consider tax increases proposed by Kohl's Christian Democrats to fill new gaps in the 1997 and 1998 budgets.
Struck said, however, that there was a possibility the SPD would support the coalition's proposal for eliminating the capital assets tax.
